title: AI detects cancer but it’s also reading who you are

summary: A missing brain molecule may be disrupting neural wiring in Down syndrome, according to new research.

summary: Scientists at Northern Arizona University are developing a promising new way to detect Alzheimer’s disease earlier than ever before—by tracking how the brain uses sugar.

summary: Anti-inflammatory medications reduce depressive symptom severity and anhedonia in individuals with depression and elevated inflammation.

summary: Taking GLP-1 medications like Ozempic is linked to a smaller risk of developing epilepsy than taking DPP-4 inhibitors.

summary: Mechanical ventilation saves lives, but the airflow it produces inside an intubated airway can also shape conditions linked to complications during long-term support.

summary: A new study shows that the embryo and the uterine lining conduct an active "conversation" from the very earliest stages of implantation.

title: Structure of dopamine-releasing neurons relates to the type of circuits they form for smell-processing, study finds
summary: Closely related subtypes of dopamine-releasing neurons may play entirely separate roles in processing sensory information, depending on their physical structure.

title: AI learns to decode the diseases written in your DNA
summary: A newly developed AI can predict which diseases specific genetic mutations are likely to cause, not just whether they are harmful.

title: Colon cancer is surging in younger adults and doctors are alarmed
summary: Cases of colorectal cancer in younger adults are climbing worldwide, driven by lifestyle changes and inherited genetic risks.

title: Scientists find the missing links between genes and disease
summary: A new genetic mapping strategy reveals how entire networks of genes work together to cause disease, filling in the missing links left by traditional genetic studies.

summary: Social isolation may accelerate cognitive decline later in life, reported a new study published in The Journals of Gerontology.

summary: The huge and diverse community of microbes in the human gastrointestinal tract is intimately linked to many aspects of our health.

title: Neurons use physical signals, not electricity, to stabilize communication
summary: Every movement you make and every memory you form depends on precise communication between neurons. When that communication is disrupted, the brain must rapidly rebalance its internal signaling to keep circuits functioning ...

title: Accelerating drug combination discovery with machine learning
summary: Discovering effective drug combinations may now be easier thanks to a screening platform made public today by St. Jude Children's Research Hospital scientists.

title: How the NIH became the backbone of American medical research and a major driver of innovation and economic growth
summary: As a young medical student in 1975, I walked into a basement lab at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland, to interview for a summer job.

title: Cannabis compounds show unexpected power against ovarian cancer
summary: Scientists have discovered that key compounds from cannabis—CBD and THC—show surprisingly strong effects against ovarian cancer cells.

title: Mayo Clinic neurosurgeon reveals 8 back pain myths to stop believing
summary: Back pain is wrapped in persistent myths, but many are far from the truth.

title: Stem cell pain sponge soaks up osteoarthritis joint pain and protects cartilage
summary: SereNeuro Therapeutics revealed promising results for SN101, a first-in-class iPSC-derived therapy designed to treat chronic osteoarthritis pain while protecting joint tissue.

title: Why consciousness exists at all
summary: Consciousness evolved in stages, starting with basic survival responses like pain and alarm, then expanding into focused awareness and self-reflection.

title: These simple habits could make your brain 8 years younger, study finds
summary: New research shows that your brain’s "true age" can shift dramatically depending on how you live, with optimism, restorative sleep, stress management, and strong social support acting like powerful anti-aging tools.

title: AI found a way to stop a virus before it enters cells
summary: Researchers discovered a hidden molecular “switch” that herpes viruses rely on to invade cells.

title: New study shows some plant-based diets may raise heart disease risk
summary: Researchers tracking over 63,000 adults found that high-quality, minimally processed plant foods significantly reduce cardiovascular risk.

title: Anxiety and insomnia linked to sharp drops in key immune cells
summary: Natural killer cells act as the immune system’s rapid-response team, but the stress of anxiety and insomnia may be quietly thinning their ranks.

title: Indoor tanning triples melanoma risk and seeds broad DNA mutations
summary: Researchers discovered that tanning beds cause widespread, mutation-laden DNA damage across almost all skin, explaining the sharply increased melanoma risk.

title: Researchers identify viral suspects that could be fueling long COVID
summary: Scientists are uncovering a new possibility behind long COVID’s stubborn symptoms: hidden infections that awaken or emerge alongside SARS-CoV-2.

title: Are Hidden Infections Linked to Long COVID?
summary: Long COVID continues to afflict many people, and confound doctors. We have learned more about various trajectories the illness can take.

title: Genetics of 14 Psychiatric Disorders Helps Explain Diagnostic Overlap
summary: A new study has provided new insights into the the genetic overlap among some psychiatric disorders, and can help explai...

title: Scientists develop mini human heart organoid that mimics atrial fibrillation
summary: Though an estimated 60 million people around the world have atrial fibrillation, or A-fib, a type of irregular and often fast heartbeat, it's been at least 30 years since any new treatments have been developed.

title: Harvard gut discovery could change how we treat obesity and diabetes
summary: Scientists found that certain molecules made by gut bacteria travel to the liver and help control how the body uses energy.

title: A grad student’s wild idea triggers a major aging breakthrough
summary: Senescent “zombie” cells are linked to aging and multiple diseases, but spotting them in living tissue has been notoriously difficult.

title: Natural compound supercharges treatment for aggressive leukemia
summary: Forskolin, a plant-derived compound, shows surprising potential against one of the most aggressive forms of leukemia.

title: AI finds a hidden stress signal inside routine CT scans
summary: Researchers used a deep learning AI model to uncover the first imaging-based biomarker of chronic stress by measuring adrenal gland volume on routine CT scans.

title: FDA drug trials exclude a widening slice of Americans, research reveals
summary: A new study finds just 6% of clinical trials used to approve new drugs in the U.S. reflect the country's racial and ethnic makeup, with an increasing trend of trials underrepresenting Black and Hispanic individuals.

title: Ozempic may offer a surprising bonus benefit for brain health
summary: A new analysis suggests that people with type 2 diabetes who use GLP-1 medications like Ozempic, Trulicity or Victoza may be less likely to develop epilepsy than those taking DPP-4 inhibitors.

title: The brain switch that could rewrite how we treat mental illness
summary: Scientists exploring how the brain responds to stress discovered molecular changes that can influence behavior long after an experience ends.

title: Kids’ anxiety and depression dropped fast after COVID school reopenings
summary: Researchers discovered that children who went back to school during COVID experienced far fewer mental health diagnoses than those who stayed remote.

title: Tea may strengthen bones in older women while heavy coffee weakens them
summary: A decade-long study of older women found that tea drinkers had slightly stronger bones, while moderate coffee drinking caused no harm.

title: AI finds a surprising monkeypox weak spot that could rewrite vaccines
summary: Researchers used AI to pinpoint a little-known monkeypox protein that provokes strong protective antibodies.

title: New discovery offers real hope for rare genetic disease
summary: Scientists discovered that certain gene changes allow cells to function even when frataxin, the protein lost in Friedreich’s ataxia, is missing.

title: Study Suggests Dispensaries Pose Harms for Their Neighborhoods
summary: A study published in the Annals of Internal Medicine found an association between community exposure to cannabis retail and increased crime rates.

title: ‘Black Religion in the Madhouse’ examines psychiatry and race post-Civil War

Nerve injuries can trigger hidden immune changes throughout the entire body
summary: Researchers discovered that nerve injuries can alter the immune system throughout the body, and males and females react very differently.

title: Scientists reveal the real benefits and hidden risks of medical cannabis
summary: A sweeping review of more than 2,500 studies reveals that despite booming public enthusiasm, cannabis has strong scientific support for only a few medical uses, leaving most popular claims—like relief for chronic pain, anxiety, and insomnia—on shaky ground.

title: Scientists find dark chocolate ingredient that slows aging
summary: Scientists have uncovered a surprising link between dark chocolate and slower aging.

title: NAD+ supplement shows early promise for long COVID fatigue and brain fog
summary: Long COVID still affects people worldwide with stubborn symptoms like fatigue and cognitive issues.

title: Daily multivitamins quietly lower blood pressure in some older adults
summary: Emerging evidence hints that daily multivitamins might quietly help certain older adults keep their blood pressure in check—especially those with poorer diets and normal readings at the start.

title: Early Earth’s belly held onto its water
How these strange cells may explain the origin of complex life
Even moderate drinking carries a bigger cancer risk than you think
summary: Researchers found that both how often and how much someone drinks significantly shape their cancer risk, even at moderate levels.

title: New research reveals how everyday cues secretly shape your habits
summary: Researchers uncovered how shifting levels of a brain protein called KCC2 can reshape the way cues become linked with rewards, sometimes making habits form more quickly or more powerfully than expected.

title: Gene-edited CAR-T cells erase aggressive T-cell leukemia
summary: A cutting-edge therapy using base-edited immune cells is offering a major breakthrough for patients with one of the toughest forms of blood cancer, T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.

title: Scientists uncover a hidden protein behind deadly mystery diseases
summary: Scientists discovered that the protein RPA plays a critical and previously unconfirmed role in stimulating telomerase to maintain long, healthy telomeres.

title: Scientists uncover the hidden survival trick that lets cancer bounce back
summary: Scientists discovered that certain cancer cells use a low-level activation of a DNA-dismantling enzyme—normally seen in cell death—to survive treatment.

title: This 15 minute hepatitis C test could change everything
summary: Northwestern scientists have created the fastest-ever hepatitis C diagnostic, delivering accurate results in only 15 minutes.

title: Bats might be the next bird flu wild card
Simple supplement mix shows remarkable results in brain cancer
summary: New research is challenging one of medicine’s oldest assumptions: that cancer must be attacked to be cured.

title: Blood tests reveal obesity rapidly accelerates Alzheimer’s progression
summary: Obesity accelerates the rise of Alzheimer’s-related blood biomarkers far more rapidly than previously recognized.

title: Scientists reveal a tiny brain chip that streams thoughts in real time
summary: BISC is an ultra-thin neural implant that creates a high-bandwidth wireless link between the brain and computers.

title: Human brains light up for chimp voices in a way no one expected
summary: Humans don’t just recognize each other’s voices—our brains also light up for the calls of chimpanzees, hinting at ancient communication roots shared with our closest primate relatives.

title: Rising temperatures are slowing early childhood development
summary: Researchers discovered that unusually high temperatures can hinder early childhood development.

title: A hidden mechanism changes what we know about cell division
summary: Researchers discovered that a long-misunderstood protein plays a key role in helping chromosomes latch onto the right “tracks” during cell division.

title: Why ultra-processed foods make teens eat more when they aren’t hungry
summary: A Virginia Tech study shows that ultra-processed foods may influence adolescents differently from slightly older young adults.

title: Some irritability is normal. Here’s when it’s not
summary: Irritability is a normal response to frustrations, but it can sometimes signal an underlying mental health disorder, like depression or anxiety.

title: Single enzyme mutation reveals a hidden trigger in dementia
summary: Researchers discovered that a tiny structural feature of the enzyme GPX4 helps keep neurons safe. A rare mutation removes this protection, allowing harmful molecules to damage cell membranes and trigger early dementia.

title: Simple light trick reveals hidden brain pathways in microscopic detail
summary: Microscopic fibers secretly shape how every organ in the body works, yet they’ve been notoriously hard to study—until now.

title: Most of the world isn’t getting enough omega-3
summary: Most people worldwide aren’t getting enough omega-3, leaving a major gap between scientific recommendations and daily diets.

title: GLP-1 drugs failed to slow Alzheimer’s in two big clinical trials
summary: Tantalizing results from small trials and anecdotes raised hopes that drugs like Ozempic could help. Despite setbacks, researchers aren’t giving up yet.

title: Drought may have doomed the ‘hobbits’ of Flores
Her food cravings vanished on Mounjaro then roared back
summary: Deep-brain recordings showed that Mounjaro and Zepbound briefly shut down the craving circuits linked to food noise in a patient with severe obesity.

title: Low dose melanoma treatment delivers dramatically better results
summary: Using less ipilimumab appears to make melanoma immunotherapy both safer and more effective, with dramatically better response and survival outcomes.

title: Garlic mouthwash shows shockingly strong germ-fighting power
summary: Garlic extract is emerging as a surprisingly powerful contender to chlorhexidine, the long-standing “gold standard” in antimicrobial mouthwashes. A systematic review of clinical studies shows that higher-concentration garlic mouthwash can rival chlorhexidine in killing bacteria—sometimes outperforming it—while offering a more natural alternative.

title: This tiny implant sends secret messages to the brain
summary: Researchers have built a fully implantable device that sends light-based messages directly to the brain. Mice learned to interpret these artificial patterns as meaningful signals, even without touch, sight, or sound.

title: Gut molecule shows remarkable anti-diabetes power
summary: Researchers revealed that the microbial metabolite TMA can directly block the immune protein IRAK4, reducing inflammation and improving insulin sensitivity.

title: New study finds a silent genetic heart risk hidden in millions
summary: A large Mayo Clinic study shows that current guidelines fail to detect nearly 90% of people with familial hypercholesterolemia, a common inherited cause of dangerously high cholesterol.

title: Scientists uncover a volcanic trigger behind the Black Death
summary: A newly analyzed set of climate data points to a major volcanic eruption that may have played a key role in the Black Death’s arrival.

title: The rotten egg smell that could finally beat nail fungus
summary: Researchers have identified hydrogen sulfide as a surprisingly effective tool for treating difficult nail infections. It penetrates nails more efficiently than current drugs and kills pathogens by disrupting their energy systems. The compound also works against fungi that resist standard antifungal treatments.

title: New fat-burning diabetes pill protects muscle and appetite
summary: Researchers have developed a new oral drug that boosts metabolic activity in muscle rather than altering appetite like GLP-1 drugs.

title: Scientists find hidden layers in brain’s memory center
summary: Scientists uncovered a surprising four-layer structure hidden inside the hippocampal CA1 region, one of the brain’s major centers for memory, navigation, and emotion.

title: A CDC panel has struck down universal newborn hepatitis B vaccination
summary: A reshaped vaccine committee voted to scale back newborn hepatitis B shots despite decades of data showing the birth dose is safe, effective and vital.

title: Scientists find hidden brain nutrient drop that may fuel anxiety
summary: Researchers found that people with anxiety disorders consistently show lower choline levels in key brain regions that regulate thinking and emotions.

title: A volcanic eruption might have helped bring the Black Plague to Europe
How a bacterial toxin linked to colon cancer messes with DNA
summary: A closeup look at colibactin’s structure reveals chemical motifs that guide its mutation-wreaking “warheads” to specific stretches of DNA.

title: Scientists capture flu viruses surfing into human cells in real time
summary: Scientists have captured a never-before-seen, high-resolution look at influenza’s stealthy invasion of human cells, revealing that the cells aren’t just helpless victims.

title: A 70-year-old pregnancy drug just revealed a hidden weakness in brain cancer
summary: Researchers have solved the decades-old mystery behind how a common pregnancy drug lowers blood pressure. It turns out the medication blocks a fast-acting “oxygen alarm” inside cells. That same alarm helps brain tumors survive, meaning the drug unexpectedly weakens them, too. The discovery could inspire better treatments for both preeclampsia and brain cancer.

title: Is your gut being poisoned? Scientists reveal the hidden impact of everyday chemicals
summary: Researchers discovered that 168 common chemicals can disrupt the growth of beneficial gut bacteria, with some also promoting antibiotic resistance. Many of these substances—found in food, water, and household items—weren’t previously suspected of affecting living organisms. A new machine learning model now predicts which chemicals may harm the microbiome. The findings suggest safety testing must expand to consider gut health.

title: A routine shingles shot may offer powerful defense against dementia
summary: A unique vaccine rollout in Wales gave researchers an accidental natural experiment that revealed a striking reduction in dementia among seniors who received the shingles vaccine.

title: Twisted stacks of 2-D carbon act like a weird type of superconductor
Self-hypnosis with cooling mental imagery could ease hot flashes
summary: Postmenopausal women who listened to self-guided hypnosis recordings daily for six weeks saw meaningful improvements in hot flash symptoms.

title: Fast depression relief? Nitrous oxide shows remarkable potential
summary: Nitrous oxide may offer quick, short-term relief for people with major depression, especially those who haven’t responded to standard medications. The meta-analysis found rapid improvements after a single dose and more sustained benefits after repeated treatments. Side effects were generally mild and brief, though researchers stress the need for larger, longer-term studies.

title: Personalized ‘prehabilitation’ helps the body brace for major surgery
summary: A small study finds that individualized prehab can dampen harmful immune responses and may reduce complications after an operation.

title: A therapeutic HPV vaccine shrank cervical tumors in mice
summary: An HPV vaccine delivered into the nose can treat cervical tumors in mice. The vaccine targets a cancer protein produced by the virus.

title: New brain imaging breakthrough reveals clues to Parkinson’s
summary: A high-speed “zap-and-freeze” method is giving scientists their clearest view yet of how brain cells send messages.

title: Scientists reveal five big moments when your brain dramatically changes
summary: A large study of brain scans shows that our neural wiring evolves through five major stages from birth to late old age.

title: Your skin has a built-in cancer defense and sunlight turns it off
summary: Scientists have uncovered how too much sunlight can flip a hidden switch inside skin cells that makes inflammation spiral out of control and increases the risk of cancer. Their research reveals that UV radiation breaks down a protective protein called YTHDF2, which normally prevents a small RNA signal from activating an immune sensor linked to dangerous inflammation. Once that protection is lost, a surprising chain reaction unfolds inside the cell, turning ordinary sun damage into a potential cancer trigger.

title: Canada just lost its measles elimination status. Is the U.S. next?
summary: Canada has had more than a year of continuous measles transmission. The United States has until January to limit cases before losing status.

title: Bird flu’s surprising heat tolerance has scientists worried
summary: Researchers discovered why bird flu can survive temperatures that stop human flu in its tracks

title: Intranasal Nanotherapy Shows Promise Against Glioblastomas
summary: A novel nasal-delivered nanotherapy has shown promise against glioblastomas in mice.

title: ‘Butt breathing’ could help people who can’t get oxygen the regular way
summary: Takanori Takebe’s strange investigation into whether humans can use the gut for breathing has surprisingly sentimental origins: helping his dad.

title: Immune Cell Activation Through a Novel Molecule Improves Cancer Therapy
summary: Immunotherapy has revolutionized the way physicians treat patients. Previously, chemotherapy was the standard-of-care wi ...

summary: Researchers recently developed a bone marrow model to study how the body generates cells. Interestingly, this model is t ...

title: Amino Acid Arginine Shows Promise for Treating Alzheimer's
summary: Amino acid arginine has shown promise in reducing the buildup of amyloid-beta plaques in animal models of Alzheimer's di ...

title: Scientists discover metformin may block key exercise benefits
summary: Rutgers scientists found that metformin can blunt many of the metabolic and cardiovascular improvements normally produced by exercise.

title: Chronic pain may dramatically raise your blood pressure
summary: Chronic pain might quietly push people toward developing high blood pressure—and the more widespread the pain, the greater the danger.

title: Prenatal Cannabis Disrupts Neurodevelopment into Adulthood
summary: Heavy cannabis use during pregnancy negatively affects fetal brain development and these effects persist into adulthood.

title: A tiny ancient virus reveals secrets that could help fight superbugs
summary: Scientists mapped the Bas63 bacteriophage in unprecedented detail, uncovering how its tail machinery infects bacteria. The structure reveals rare whisker-collar features and distant evolutionary ties reaching back billions of years. These insights could guide new phage therapies and innovations in medicine, agriculture, and industry.

title: GLP-1 drugs like Ozempic deliver huge weight loss but new research reveals a hidden catch
summary: GLP-1 drugs like tirzepatide and semaglutide offer powerful weight-loss effects but come with unanswered questions about long-term safety, side effects, and global accessibility. Researchers stress the need for independent studies before these treatments can be fully embraced worldwide.

title: How Gut-Brain Signaling Reduces Post-lllness Appetite
summary: After an illness like the flu, symptoms may go away while a person still feels lousy. Researchers wanted to learn more a ...

title: Gum Disease Linked to Brain White Matter Damage
summary: Older adults with gum disease have more signs of brain white matter damage than those with good periodontal health.

title: Scientists reverse kidney damage in mice, hope for humans next
summary: Researchers uncovered how fatty molecules called ceramides trigger acute kidney injury by damaging the mitochondria that power kidney cells. By altering ceramide metabolism or using a new drug candidate, the team was able to protect mitochondrial function and completely prevent kidney injury in mice.

title: New discovery could help stop diabetes damage at its source
summary: Scientists identified a small molecule that interrupts a harmful protein pair linked to diabetic inflammation and tissue damage. The compound helped wounds heal faster and reduced organ stress in both Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes models. Unlike typical treatments, it works by blocking damaging signals rather than lowering sugar levels. The results point to a new direction for treating diabetes complications.

title: CRISPR brings back ancient gene that prevents gout and fatty liver
summary: By reactivating a long-lost gene, researchers were able to lower uric acid levels and stop damaging fat accumulation in human liver models. The breakthrough hints at a future where gout and several metabolic diseases could be prevented at the genetic level.

title: Microgravity Muscle Printing Paves Way for Space Biomanufacturing
summary: Can muscle tissue be 3D-printed in outer space to improve astronaut health? This is what a recent study published in Adv ...

title: Engineered Antibody Improves Treatment for Autoimmune Disorders
summary: Autoimmune disorders occur when the body’s immune system cannot differentiate between cells that are its own and p ...

title: A tiny worm just revealed a big secret about living longer
summary: Scientists studying aging found that sensory inputs like touch and smell can cancel out the lifespan-boosting effects of dietary restriction by suppressing the key longevity gene fmo-2. When overactivated, the gene makes worms oddly indifferent to danger and food, suggesting trade-offs between lifespan and behavior. The work highlights how deeply intertwined the brain, metabolism, and environment are. These pathways may eventually be targeted to extend life without extreme dieting.

title: Op-Ed: Death During Treatment is Unacceptable in the Era of Precision Medicine: Why Should this Be?
summary: In the 21st century, oncology has achieved extraordinary progress. We can decode a tumor’s genome, tailor therapie...

title: About Half of Heart Attacks Occur in "Low Risk" People
summary: Current calculators may not accurately predict your risk of having a heart attack.

title: Cannabis Access Tied to Reduced Opioid Use
summary: What impact can cannabis have on opioid use? This is what a recent study published in JAMA Internal Medicine hopes to address.

title: Recreational Cannabis Affects Teens with Psychiatric Illness
summary: More adolescents seeking help for a psychiatric emergency in Massachusetts were using cannabis following the substance's legalization.

title: Diet Improves Immune Cell Function
summary: Scientists at the Van Andel Research Institute found that reducing caloric intake can help immune cells fight cancer. Co ...

summary: Reflecting on a year of Chromatography Life, Neil Lander highlights...

title: Biomedical authors often call a reference 'recent'—even when it is decades old, analysis shows
summary: Authors in biomedical journals frequently describe cited evidence as "recent," yet the actual age of the references behind these phrases has rarely been measured.

title: Blocking collagen signaling boosts drug delivery in pancreatic cancer
summary: Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest malignancies, with survival rates remaining dismally low despite major advances in oncology.

title: Rats may seek cannabis to cope with stress
summary: It isn't just people—when given the chance, rats may also use cannabis to cope with stress, according to a study by researchers at Washington State University.

title: Fake participants and bots threaten quality of online research data
summary: Recruiting participants for injury and violence-related studies can be challenging.

title: Diversity language in US medical research agency grants declined 25% since 2024, analysis finds
summary: Words reflecting diversity language have appeared less frequently in grants awarded by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) since the 2024 US presidential election, with a 25% relative decrease between January 2024 and ...

title: Helping ICU patients regain independence: How early rehabilitation can speed recovery
summary: A multicenter study across Japan found that ICU patients receiving more intensive rehabilitation regained independence faster after critical illness.

title: Strange microscopic structures found in Long COVID blood
summary: Scientists have discovered strange microscopic structures in the blood of people with Long COVID—clusters of tiny microclots tangled together with sticky immune webs known as neutrophil extracellular traps, or NETs. These combined structures show up far more often in Long COVID patients, where they appear larger, denser, and more stubborn than in healthy blood.

title: Scientists find 15 gut bacteria that may drive heart disease
summary: Scientists in Seoul have uncovered 15 gut bacterial species linked to coronary artery disease, showing that microbes can influence heart health far beyond digestion. Their findings reveal how shifts in gut microbial function — including inflammation, loss of protective species, and overactive metabolic pathways — may drive disease progression. Intriguingly, even “good” bacteria like Faecalibacterium prausnitzii and Akkermansia muciniphila can become harmful under certain conditions.

title: The Mechanism Behind a Common Virus is Revealed
summary: Astroviruses may not be well known, but they are very common and are the leading cause of diarrhea in children...

title: The Early Life Gut Microbiome is Linked to Emotional Health
summary: Scientists have now found that the composition of the gut microbiome during childhood can have an influence on whether a ...

title: Tiny implant wipes out bladder cancer in 82% of patients
summary: TAR-200, a small drug-releasing implant, wiped out tumors in most patients with high-risk bladder cancer. Its slow, consistent release of chemotherapy proved far more effective than traditional short-term treatments. The therapy may replace bladder removal surgery for many and has earned FDA Priority Review due to its impressive results.

title: New online tool can predict how well blood pressure drugs will work
summary: A new blood pressure calculator built on extensive clinical trial data helps doctors accurately estimate how much each medication will reduce blood pressure. The tool simplifies complex treatment choices and replaces unreliable BP measurements with solid evidence.

title: AI unravels the hidden communication of gut microbes
summary: Scientists have turned to advanced AI to decode the intricate ecosystem of gut bacteria and their chemical signals. Using a Bayesian neural network called VBayesMM, researchers can now identify genuine biological links rather than random correlations. The system has already outperformed traditional models in studies of obesity, sleep disorders, and cancer.
